claim_text: In Costa Rica, over 98% of electricity is generated from renewable sources, helping the country achieve nearly universal access without a significant increase in its carbon footprint.
Uruguay has achieved 100% electricity access while generating approximately 98% of its power from renewables, keeping its per capita emissions low.
Kenya has rapidly increased its electricity access rate to over 71%, while keeping its per capita carbon footprint very low at around 0.3 metric tons.
Kenya's per capita carbon footprint is approximately 0.3 metric tons, one of the lowest in the world, despite major increases in electricity availability.
Iceland runs on 100% renewable electricity, primarily from geothermal and hydropower, resulting in a low per capita carbon footprint for a developed nation.
Costa Rica's CO2 emissions per capita are around 1.6 metric tons, a low figure for a country with its level of development and electricity access.
West Virginia, a state with significant coal industry presence, has the highest rate of COPD in the nation, with 13.6% of its adult population diagnosed with the disease.
Kentucky, another major coal state, has the second-highest COPD rate in the US at 12.3%.
In 2023, Wyoming was the state most dependent on coal for electricity, generating 71% of its power from coal.
In 2023, coal was the largest source of electricity generation in 18 states.
Smoking is the primary cause of COPD, accounting for about 8 out of 10 COPD-related deaths.
According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the prevalence of obesity among U.S. adults was 41.9% in 2017 – March 2020.
The prevalence of adult obesity in the U.S. increased from 30.5% in 1999–2000 to 41.9% in 2017-March 2020.
The prevalence of severe obesity among adults increased from 4.7% to 9.2% between 1999-2000 and 2017-March 2020.
For youth aged 2-19, the obesity prevalence was 19.7% in 2017-2020, affecting about 14.7 million children and adolescents.
In 2017-2020, obesity affected about 14.7 million U.S. children and adolescents.

claim_text: According to a report by India's Ministry of Earth Sciences, the average temperature over India is projected to rise by approximately 4.4 degrees Celsius by the end of the 21st century (relative to 1976-2005) under a high-emission scenario (RCP8.5).

The Hindu Kush Himalayan region, which includes states like Jammu & Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand, and Sikkim, is projected to experience a more pronounced warming, with a temperature rise of about 5.2 degrees Celsius by the end of the century under the same high-emission scenario.
Under a lower emission scenario (RCP4.5), the projected average temperature rise for India by the end of the century is about 2.7 degrees Celsius.
The frequency of summer heatwaves over India is projected to be 3 to 4 times higher by the end of the 21st century under the RCP8.5 scenario.

Yes, there is a strong and well-documented correlation between gender inequality and poverty in Africa. Numerous studies and reports from organizations like the World Bank, United Nations, and African Development Bank show that gender inequality is a major driver of poverty, and conversely, poverty often exacerbates gender inequality. This creates a vicious cycle that is difficult to break. The economic cost of gender inequality in the workforce is estimated to cost sub-Saharan Africa about $95 billion each year.

In sub-Saharan Africa, women and girls collectively spend an estimated 40 billion hours a year collecting water, which is time that could be spent on education, income-generating activities, or community involvement.

The region of Sub-Saharan Africa accounts for approximately 70% of the world's maternal deaths, a clear indicator of women's poor access to healthcare, which is both a cause and consequence of poverty.
Globally, for every additional year of primary school a girl attends, her future wages increase by 10-20%.
In North Africa, women account for only 5% of agricultural landholders, limiting their ability to generate income, access credit, and escape poverty.
According to India's 2011 Census, 65.49 million people lived in slums.
The 2011 Census of India found that 17.4% of the country's urban population lived in slums.
The slum population identified in the 2011 Census constituted 5.4% of India's total population at the time.
World Bank data from 2018 estimated that 24% of India's urban population lived in slums.
UN-Habitat estimated that in 2020, approximately 35% of India's urban population resided in slums.
In the majority of OECD countries, more women than men are attaining tertiary education, a reversal of historical trends.
Across OECD countries, 52% of women aged 25-34 hold a tertiary degree.
Across OECD countries, 39% of men aged 25-34 hold a tertiary degree.
In Canada, 72% of women aged 25-34 have a tertiary qualification.
In Canada, 59% of men aged 25-34 have a tertiary qualification.
In Australia, 63% of women aged 25-34 have completed tertiary education.
In Australia, 49% of men aged 25-34 have completed tertiary education.
In the United States, 50% of women aged 25-64 have a tertiary degree.
In the United States, 42% of men aged 25-64 have a tertiary degree.

The Donohue-Levitt hypothesis, proposed in a 2001 paper, attributed as much as 50% of the crime drop in the 1990s to the legalization of abortion.
A 2019 follow-up paper by the original authors, Donohue and Levitt, argued that legalized abortion accounted for a 45% drop in crime between 1991 and 2014.

claim_text: The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics does not calculate a specific Consumer Price Index (CPI) for the state of North Carolina; instead, it provides data for the broader South region, which saw the CPI for All Urban Consumers (CPI-U) increase by 3.4 percent over the 12 months from July 2022 to July 2023.
For comparison, the national U.S. inflation rate for all items increased by 3.2 percent over the same period from July 2022 to July 2023.
Within the South region, the food index increased by 5.1 percent from July 2022 to July 2023.
The energy index in the South region decreased by 13.9 percent over the 12 months ending in July 2023.
The index for all items less food and energy (core inflation) in the South region rose by 4.9 percent from July 2022 to July 2023.

Immediately following a sold-out Hawks game, traffic volume on the Downtown Connector (I-75/85) can increase by as much as 50% in the first hour.

This period of heavy post-game congestion typically lasts for about 60 to 90 minutes before traffic levels begin to normalize.
Travel times on major surface streets near the arena can increase by up to 200% (triple the normal time) during the post-game rush.

claim_text: According to the Bank for International Settlements (BIS), China's total credit to the non-financial sector reached 295.5% of its GDP in the third quarter of 2023.

The BIS also calculates a 'credit-to-GDP gap,' which measures the deviation of the credit-to-GDP ratio from its long-term trend. For China, this gap was 16.9 percentage points in the third quarter of 2023.
The BIS considers a credit-to-GDP gap above 10 percentage points to be a potential early warning signal for financial stress.

Historically, during recessions, defensive sectors such as Consumer Staples, Healthcare, and Utilities have outperformed the broader market.
A study analyzing recessions since 1980 found that the Healthcare sector had the highest average return, outperforming the S&P 500 by an average of 10.1% during recessionary periods.
In the same study of recessions since 1980, the Consumer Staples sector outperformed the S&P 500 by an average of 8.4%.
The Utilities sector, in a study of recessions since 1980, outperformed the S&P 500 by an average of 7.7%.
In contrast, cyclical sectors like Information Technology tend to be the worst performers, underperforming the S&P 500 by an average of 8.8% during recessions since 1980.

In the 2019 Indian general election, 201 out of 543 Lok Sabha seats changed their winning party compared to the 2014 election.
The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) was the largest beneficiary of the flipped seats, gaining 92 constituencies from other parties in 2019.
The Indian National Congress (INC) was the biggest loser among the flipped seats, ceding 57 of its previously held constituencies to other parties.
In Tamil Nadu, the DMK-led alliance won 38 out of 39 seats in 2019, a major reversal from 2014 when the AIADMK won 37 seats.
In West Bengal, the BJP increased its seat count from 2 in 2014 to 18 in 2019.
In Andhra Pradesh, the YSRCP won 22 seats in 2019, a significant increase from the 8 seats it won in 2014.
In late 2023, the Kerala government informed the Supreme Court that the Governor was withholding assent on eight bills passed by the state assembly.
The Tamil Nadu government approached the Supreme Court stating that the Governor was delaying assent for 12 bills.
In Punjab, a major point of contention was the Governor withholding assent from at least four bills, arguing the assembly session in which they were passed was illegal.
For a new college graduate joining a major investment bank as a first-year analyst, the sign-on bonus typically ranges from $10,000 to $25,000.
In addition to a sign-on bonus, the base salary for a first-year investment banking analyst at a large bank is often around $110,000.
First-year analysts can also expect a year-end 'stub' bonus, which can range from $30,000 to $50,000.
India has a significantly larger rural population than urban, with 68.84% of its people living in rural areas as of the 2011 Census.

In terms of percentage, Goa is the most urbanized state, with 62.17% of its population residing in urban centers.

In terms of absolute numbers, Uttar Pradesh has the second-largest urban population with 44.5 million people.

In Tarn Taran district, Punjab, Sikhs account for 93.33% of the population, making them the majority religious group in the district.

In 2020, the maternal mortality ratio in Sub-Saharan Africa was estimated at 531 deaths per 100,000 live births, accounting for roughly 70% of the global total.
In Sub-Saharan Africa, the coverage of births attended by skilled health personnel was approximately 68% in 2021.
The coverage of at least four antenatal care (ANC) visits in sub-Saharan Africa was around 64% in 2021.
The adolescent birth rate in Africa is the highest in the world, at 99 births per 1,000 women aged 15-19.
The modern contraceptive prevalence rate among all women of reproductive age in Sub-Saharan Africa was estimated at 29% in 2019.
According to a 2023 report, the Mexican city of Colima was ranked as the most violent in the world with a homicide rate of 181.94 per 100,000 inhabitants.

The city of Zamora, Mexico had a homicide rate of 177.7 per 100,000 people.
Ciudad Obregón, Mexico had a homicide rate of 138.2 per 100,000 people.

A 2023 study of Southern California found that for every 10 microgram per cubic meter increase in wildfire-specific fine particulate matter (PM2.5), there was an associated 3.2% increase in asthma-related emergency department visits.

Research on the 2020 wildfire season in the western U.S. estimated that in Washington state, wildfire smoke was responsible for 19.7% of all asthma-related emergency department visits during the smoke period.

A Stanford-led study found that a 10 microgram per cubic meter increase in PM2.5 from wildfire smoke was associated with up to a 10% increase in daily pediatric asthma emergency department visits in some regions.
The relationship between population density and COVID-19 death rates is complex and not a direct correlation; many other factors were more significant predictors of mortality.
The United States, with a relatively low population density of about 36 people per square kilometer, had a high mortality rate, exceeding 300 deaths per 100,000 people.
Conversely, Singapore, one of the most densely populated places in the world with nearly 8,000 people per square kilometer, maintained a very low death rate through effective public health measures.
At certain points during the pandemic, Singapore's death rate was as low as 28 deaths per 100,000 people, far lower than many less dense countries.
Peru, with a low population density of about 25 people per square kilometer, suffered one of the highest mortality rates in the world.
Peru's COVID-19 death rate exceeded 600 deaths per 100,000 people, highlighting the impact of factors like healthcare infrastructure over simple population density.
In Rwanda, a 2003 constitution mandated that at least 30% of parliamentary seats be reserved for women, a key factor in its political transformation.
By 2019, women held 61.3% of the seats in Rwanda's lower house of parliament, the highest proportion in the world.
After Senegal passed a gender parity law in 2010, the proportion of women in its parliament surged from 22% to 42.7% in the 2012 elections.
In South Africa, following the end of apartheid and the adoption of voluntary party quotas, female representation in parliament grew to 44.5% by 2009.
Through a system of affirmative action seats established in its 1995 constitution, female representation in Uganda's parliament reached 34.9% by 2016.

There is no direct correlation suggesting that US counties where the Health Care industry is the largest employer also have the highest rates of chronic conditions; in fact, the presence of large medical centers that drive employment often exists in counties with average or better-than-average health outcomes for the resident population.
According to the CDC, 6 in 10 adults in the US have a chronic disease.
The CDC reports that 4 in 10 adults in the US have two or more chronic diseases.
The Health Care and Social Assistance sector is one of the largest employers in the U.S., providing approximately 22 million jobs.
The 'youth bulge' theory suggests that when individuals aged 15 to 29 make up more than 30% of the population, there is a significantly increased risk of social unrest, war, and terrorism.
A 2007 World Bank report found that countries where young adults (aged 15-24) comprised over 20% of the adult population had a significantly higher risk of experiencing a civil conflict outbreak.
topic: Youth population and civil conflict risk

claim_text: Massachusetts has one of the highest concentrations of advanced degree holders, with approximately 2.5% of its population aged 25 and over holding a doctorate.

Despite its public school system often ranking lower, New Mexico has a high concentration of PhDs, with about 2.1% of its adult population holding a doctorate, largely due to the presence of national research laboratories.
Several analyses have identified Hillsborough County, Florida, as one of the counties that most closely mirrors the demographic profile of the United States as a whole.
The median age in the United States is approximately 38.8 years.
The U.S. population is about 50.8% female.
According to the 2020 Census, the U.S. is approximately 61.6% White (non-Hispanic), 18.7% Hispanic, 12.4% Black (non-Hispanic), and 6% Asian (non-Hispanic).
New Haven County, Connecticut, is often cited as a demographic microcosm of the U.S., with a median age of 39.4, very close to the national figure.
In Hillsborough County, Florida, the Hispanic population is about 29.5%, which is higher than the national average but contributes to its overall diversity mix that makes it a bellwether.
In rural Vietnam, a World Bank study found that households with electricity saw their incomes increase by as much as 35% over five years compared to unelectrified households.
A study in Kenya found that household electrification increased the total time children spent on homework by 25%.

The World Health Organization estimates that more than 50% of vaccines are wasted globally every year, with a significant portion of this waste attributed to a broken cold chain, often due to a lack of reliable electricity.
In India, access to electricity was found to increase the probability of a non-farm business starting by 29%.

The WHO reports that around 3.2 million people a year die prematurely from illness attributable to household air pollution caused by the inefficient use of solid fuels and kerosene, which can be replaced by electric appliances.
Research in rural India showed that access to electricity can free up to 1.5 hours of a woman's day, time previously spent on tasks like collecting fuel or water.
In the 2020 election, Wyoming was Trump's highest-margin state, where he won by approximately 43.3 percentage points.
West Virginia, a high-margin Trump state, has the lowest percentage of adults (25+) with a bachelor's degree or higher in the U.S., at 24.1%.
The population of West Virginia is 92.1% non-Hispanic White, reflecting the lower racial diversity in high-margin Trump states.
The District of Columbia was Biden's highest-margin area, where he won by approximately 86.7 percentage points.
Among states, Massachusetts has the highest educational attainment, with 46.6% of adults holding a bachelor's degree or higher.
Maryland, a high-margin Biden state, has one of the highest median household incomes in the nation, at over $90,000.
Reflecting high urbanization in strong Biden states, over 92% of the population in Massachusetts lives in urban areas.
The District of Columbia has the highest educational attainment in the nation, with 64.6% of adults holding a bachelor's degree.
The population of Cambridge, MA is approximately 117,090.
The population of Palo Alto, CA is approximately 67,094.
The median age in Cambridge is 30.5 years, significantly younger than Palo Alto's 41.9 years.
The median age in Palo Alto is 41.9 years.
In Cambridge, approximately 81.3% of residents aged 25 and older hold a bachelor's degree or higher.
In Palo Alto, approximately 83.4% of residents aged 25 and older hold a bachelor's degree or higher.
The median household income in Cambridge is approximately $121,539.
The median household income in Palo Alto is substantially higher at approximately $214,750.
Palo Alto has a lower poverty rate of about 5.2%.
Cambridge has a poverty rate of about 11.5%.
Palo Alto's population is approximately 34.4% Asian.
Cambridge's population is approximately 19.4% Asian.
In 2022, the mean age of mothers at first birth in the United States was 27.4 years.
The birth rate for teenagers aged 15–19 in the U.S. was 13.5 births per 1,000 females in 2022, a decline of 3% from 2021.
In 2021, the general fertility rate for Hispanic women was 62.0 births per 1,000 women aged 15-44, the highest among major U.S. racial and ethnic groups.
Among women age 15 to 50 who had a birth in the past year, 41.0% had a bachelor's degree or higher as of 2022.
Birth rates for women aged 35–39 rose to 55.6 births per 1,000 in 2022.

claim_text: In October 2023, Odisha recorded one of the highest food inflation rates among major Indian states at 10.1%.
During the same period (October 2023), housing inflation in Odisha was significantly lower, at 3.9%.
Haryana also experienced very high food inflation at 9.4% in October 2023.
In contrast to its high food inflation, Haryana's housing inflation for the same month was a more moderate 5.6%.
For context, the all-India average food inflation rate for October 2023 was 6.61%.
The all-India average housing inflation rate for October 2023 was 4.46%.
China is the world's largest consumer of electricity, accounting for approximately 30% of the global total.
The United States is the second-largest consumer, responsible for about 15% of global electricity consumption.
France is a leading electricity exporter, sending over 10% of its total generation to neighboring countries.
Germany was the largest net exporter of electricity in Europe in 2023, with a surplus of 19.7 terawatt-hours.
Paraguay exports over 85% of its electricity production, making it the world's largest net exporter relative to its production.
Canada is a major net exporter, sending roughly 57 terawatt-hours of electricity to the United States annually.
Kern County is a major agricultural producer, with the total gross value of all agricultural commodities in 2022 reaching $8,079,067,000.
The agricultural value in Kern County represented a 2.3% decrease from the 2021 total.
In 2022, grapes were the county's top commodity, with a total value of $1,478,592,000.
Almonds (including by-products) were the second most valuable commodity in Kern County in 2022, valued at $1,209,771,000.
Milk ranked as the third most valuable commodity in 2022, with a gross value of $1,001,844,000.
Pistachios were the fourth leading commodity in Kern County in 2022, with a value of $867,460,000.

claim_text: In the United States, approximately 56.2% of households with incomes below the federal poverty level received SNAP benefits in 2022.
The SNAP participation rate for households below the poverty line in the District of Columbia was approximately 67.1% in 2022.
In Oregon, the SNAP participation rate among households below the poverty line was approximately 66.5% in 2022.
In Texas, the SNAP participation rate among households below the poverty line was about 45.6% in 2022.
Wyoming had one of the lowest SNAP participation rates for poor households in 2022, at around 30.9%.

According to the U.S. Census Bureau's American Community Survey (2018-2022), the average household size in California is 2.93 persons.

Among the states listed, New York City, New York consistently ranks as one of the most expensive rental markets, with the median rent for a one-bedroom apartment recently reported at $4,200.

During the Great Recession, the Case-Shiller Home Price Index for the San Francisco metro area experienced a peak-to-trough decline of approximately 46% between its peak in mid-2007 and its bottom in early 2012.
Following the dot-com bust, the median home price in Santa Clara County fell by about 8% from 2001 to 2002.
From a peak in April 2022, the median home price in the Bay Area dropped by about 15% by the start of 2023 due to rising interest rates.
During the early 1990s recession, the median home price in the Bay Area fell by about 10% from its peak in 1990 to its trough around 1996.
Several East Asian countries leveraged experience from the 2003 SARS outbreak to inform their COVID-19 testing and response strategies.
By early March 2020, South Korea had rapidly scaled its testing capacity, enabling it to test up to 20,000 people per day.
In contrast to early successes elsewhere, the United States' initial rollout was slow, having conducted only about 5 tests per million people by early March 2020.
By late 2020, the small, wealthy nation of Denmark had conducted a cumulative total of more than 20 million tests.
An analysis of data from 2005 to 2019 showed that 48 of the 50 U.S. counties with the highest suicide rates were located in the West.
The suicide rate in rural counties is approximately 1.8 times higher than in the most urban counties.
According to the National Family Health Survey (NFHS-5, 2019-21), institutional births across India have reached 89%.
The rate of institutional births in India has increased from 79% in NFHS-4 (2015-16).
In 2005-06 (NFHS-3), the rate of institutional births in India was only 39%.
Several states and Union Territories, including Puducherry and Tamil Nadu, have achieved over 99% institutional births.
Nagaland has the lowest rate of institutional births in India, at 58.2%.
The rate of institutional births in urban areas of India is 94.1%.
The rate of institutional births in rural areas of India is 87%.

In Chattahoochee County, Georgia, which has one of the highest veteran population percentages in the U.S., veterans comprise approximately 45.6% of the adult civilian population.
In Chattahoochee County, Georgia, a county with a high veteran population, the population is approximately 89.5% native-born.
In Miami-Dade County, Florida, which has one of the lowest veteran population percentages, veterans make up about 2.5% of the adult civilian population.
In Miami-Dade County, Florida, a county with a low veteran population percentage, the foreign-born population is approximately 53%, outnumbering the native-born population.
Based on data from the U.S. Census Bureau's 2022 American Community Survey, the overall disability prevalence rates in Dallas and Houston are nearly identical, at 8.8% and 8.7% respectively.
Based on data from the U.S. Census Bureau's 2022 American Community Survey, the overall disability prevalence rates in Dallas and Houston are nearly identical, at 8.8% and 8.7% respectively.
The prevalence of ambulatory (mobility) difficulty is identical in both cities, with 4.8% of the civilian noninstitutionalized population in both Dallas and Houston reporting this type of disability.
Cognitive difficulty affects 4.2% of the population in Dallas and 4.1% in Houston, showing a negligible difference.
Cognitive difficulty affects 4.2% of the population in Dallas and 4.1% in Houston, showing a negligible difference.
For vision difficulty, the rates are 3.1% in Dallas and 3.2% in Houston.

Based on 2021 CDC data, Wisconsin has the highest prevalence of adult binge drinking, with 25.9% of adults reporting binge drinking in the past 30 days.
According to 2021 CDC data, Utah has the lowest prevalence of adult binge drinking, at 10.8%.
West Virginia consistently has one of the highest adult smoking rates, with recent data showing it at 23.6%.
Utah reports the lowest adult smoking rate in the nation, at 8.5%.
While national data shows a return to pre-COVID levels, the recovery in unemployment insurance claims at the U.S. county level has been uneven.
At the peak of the pandemic's impact, weekly initial unemployment claims in the U.S. surged to 6.87 million for the week ending March 28, 2020.
In 2019, prior to the pandemic, weekly initial unemployment claims in the U.S. averaged approximately 218,000.
By early 2024, national weekly initial claims had returned to a range comparable to pre-pandemic levels, with 212,000 claims filed in the week ending April 20, 2024.

When comparing total railway route length, the major states in northern India generally have a more extensive network than those in the south. For instance, as of March 31, 2021, the northern state of Uttar Pradesh has the largest railway network in the country, with a total route length of 9,100 kilometers.
The northern state of Rajasthan has a railway network spanning 6,019 kilometers.
Among the southern states, Tamil Nadu has the most extensive network with 4,190 kilometers of route length.
In terms of rail density (route km per 1,000 sq. km), the northern state of Punjab has one of the highest in the country, with 45.3 route kilometers per 1,000 square kilometers of area.
By comparison, the southern state of Tamil Nadu has a rail density of 32.2 route kilometers per 1,000 square kilometers.
The southern state of Kerala has a total railway route length of 1,050 kilometers.
In 2019, the world generated a record 53.6 million metric tonnes of electronic waste.
In 2019, the top three e-waste generating countries in absolute terms were China, the United States, and India.
China generated 10.1 million metric tonnes of e-waste in 2019.
The United States generated 6.9 million metric tonnes of e-waste in 2019.
India generated 3.2 million metric tonnes of e-waste in 2019.
Europe had the highest per capita generation of e-waste in 2019.
Norway had the world's highest per capita e-waste generation in 2019.
An estimated 931 million tonnes of food waste were generated globally in 2019, with 61% of this coming from households.
In high-income countries, the average consumer wastes between 95 and 115 kg of food per year.
In low-income countries, the average consumer wastes between 6 and 11 kg of food per year.
The prevalence of undernourishment in high-income regions like North America and Europe is typically below 2.5%.
Globally, between 691 and 783 million people faced hunger in 2022.
The United States is the largest source country for remittances, with outflows reaching $79 billion in 2022.
Saudi Arabia was the second largest source of remittances in 2022, with outflows of $39 billion.
India was projected to be the largest recipient of remittances in 2023, with total inflows of over $125 billion.
In 2022, remittances to Tajikistan were equivalent to 51% of its Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
For Tonga, inward remittances constituted 44% of its GDP in 2022.
In Lebanon, inward remittances were equivalent to 36% of its GDP in 2022.
Officially recorded remittance flows to low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) were estimated to reach $669 billion in 2023.
The growth of remittance flows to low- and middle-income countries was estimated at 3.8% in 2023.
In the United States, the share of adults who owned a smartphone grew from just 35% in 2011 to 85% by 2021, with the most rapid growth occurring in the early to mid-2010s.
In the United States, the share of adults who owned a smartphone grew to 85% by 2021.

In India, the mobile usage spike was catalyzed by the launch of the Reliance Jio 4G network in late 2016, which caused data prices to plummet and led to a surge in adoption; by 2022, the country had over 600 million smartphone users.
In Brazil, the major spike in smartphone usage occurred in the mid-2010s; as of May 2022, the country had 242 million active smartphones in use, which is more than its population.

According to the most recent comprehensive report from the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) for 2015, California withdraws the most water of any state, with total withdrawals estimated at 38,400 million gallons per day.
The largest county in California by land area is San Bernardino County, which covers approximately 20,105 square miles.
The largest county in California by population is Los Angeles County, with a population of over 10 million people.
Between 2010 and 2020, China achieved the highest average annual net gain in forest area, adding an estimated 1.9 million hectares per year.
According to the India State of Forest Report 2021, India's forest and tree cover increased by 2,261 square kilometers between the 2019 and 2021 assessments.
Vietnam's forest cover increased from approximately 28% of its land area in 1990 to over 42% by 2020.
The forest area in the European Union increased by approximately 9% between 1990 and 2020.
Ireland's forest cover has grown from a low of 1% in the early 20th century to approximately 11% today.
In US counties with a poverty rate of 29% or more, the median prevalence of short sleep duration was 39.7%.
In US counties with a poverty rate of less than 13%, the median prevalence of short sleep duration was 31.6%.
Short sleep duration is defined as getting less than 7 hours of sleep per 24-hour period.
In US counties with an unemployment rate of 9.3% or more, the median prevalence of short sleep was 38.3%.
In US counties with an unemployment rate of less than 5.1%, the median prevalence of short sleep was 32.1%.

In many U.S. counties, such as Utah County, Utah, the percentage of married people is higher than the percentage of people who have never been married. In Utah County, about 58% of the population 15 and over is married.
In Utah County, Utah, approximately 32% of the population aged 15 and over has never been married.

There are no U.S. counties where divorced people outnumber married people. Even in counties with high divorce rates, like Storey County, Nevada, the divorced population is about 18%, while the married population is about 51%.
In Storey County, Nevada, which has one of the higher divorce rates, the married population is about 51%.
In 2023, virtually 100% of Vermont's in-state electricity generation came from renewable resources.
In 2023, wind and hydropower combined accounted for 84% of South Dakota's total electricity generation.
topic: South Dakota electricity generation from renewables

claim_text: Renewable resources, primarily hydropower, supplied 78% of Idaho's total in-state electricity net generation in 2023.
In 2023, renewable energy resources, led by conventional hydropower, generated 77% of Washington's total in-state electricity.
In 2023, renewable energy sources accounted for 76% of Maine's total in-state electricity generation.
In 2023, Iowa generated 64% of its electricity from renewable resources, with wind power being the largest source.
Renewable energy sources provided 62% of Montana's in-state electricity generation in 2023, led by hydropower and wind.
In 2023, renewable energy resources generated 60% of Oregon's utility-scale electricity.
Renewable resources, mostly wind power, supplied 48% of Kansas's total electricity net generation in 2023, exceeding the 42% from coal and natural gas combined.
In 2021, women earned 54.1% of all doctorates awarded to U.S. citizens and permanent residents.
The on-time graduation rate for public high school students in the 2019-20 school year was 88% for females.

claim_text: According to 2022 data from the WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP), 703 million people worldwide still lacked a basic drinking water service.
A basic drinking water service is defined as an improved water source, such as a piped connection or protected well, that is within a 30-minute round trip for water collection.
Sub-Saharan Africa has the lowest rates of access, with only 60% of the population having at least a basic service.
Eight out of ten people without basic water services live in rural areas.
In the Central African Republic, only 37% of the population has access to basic drinking water.
In Chad, approximately 43% of the population has access to basic drinking water services.
In 2022, 115 million people still collected drinking water directly from surface water sources like rivers and lakes.
The rate of opioid prescriptions in California decreased by nearly 50% between 2013 and 2020.
California's opioid prescription rate fell from 700 per 1,000 residents in 2013 to 358 per 1,000 residents in 2020.
In 2020, the opioid prescription rate in Shasta County was among the state's highest at 805 per 1,000 residents.
In 2020, Santa Clara County had one of the state's lowest opioid prescription rates at 196 per 1,000 residents.
While opioid prescriptions have declined, prescriptions for stimulants like amphetamines have been increasing.
From 2016 through 2019, the number of individuals in California prescribed buprenorphine, a medication to treat opioid use disorder, increased by 72 percent.
In Los Alamos County, New Mexico, one of the counties with the highest concentration of PhDs, about 18.7% of the population aged 25 and over holds a doctorate degree.
In Arlington County, Virginia, a high-income area, approximately 10.1% of adults 25 and over have a doctorate degree.
In Falls Church, Virginia, which often has the highest median household income in the country, about 9.9% of the population 25 and over holds a doctorate.
Across the entire United States, approximately 2% of the population aged 25 and older has a doctorate degree.
